Award.AbstractNarration:
Title: Study of Optical Modulators Based on Novel Material Graphene

Abstract
Nontechnical: With the advent of new applications such as social media, online medical records, cloud computing there is an astronomical increase in the data that is transmitted over the Internet and within the data centers. The only viable technology to transmit such vast amounts of information on demand is the fiber optics technology. This relies on transmitting optical radiation through optical fiber. However information is almost always available in electrical form. Transmitting electrical information over the optical fiber requires optical modulators. Optical modulator imposes electrical information on the optical radiation which transports electrical information over the optical fiber. Optical modulators are needed in large quantities and are desired to be very compact, low power consuming and low cost. Furthermore their technology should allow integration with other devices to form high functionality microchips. This proposal investigates the possibility of such modulators in a novel material called graphene. Graphene is an arrangement of mono layer thick carbon atoms. Therefore the proposed effort has the potential to benefit the society and make a significant contribution to quality of life through lower cost, higher performance data transmission using fiber optics.

Technical: This proposal introduces a high risk and high reward approach for optical modulators. This is based on unique electro-optic properties of graphene. Commonly used theoretical formulas that describe conductivity of graphene suggest huge changes in real and imaginary parts of graphene dielectric constant when Fermi level in graphene is changed. This suggests very compact and efficient optical modulation. In particular using two graphene sheets separated by a thin dielectric can be used to generate very large effective index changes in a very compact dielectric waveguide. Modeling based on this theoretical analysis indicates modulator performance significantly better than the state of the art even without significant optimization. The rewards could be much bigger with careful optimization and design. However, there are significant unknowns that may limit these predictions. This proposal investigates the veracity of these ideas to see if graphene can be utilized for superior modulators that will be the work horse of next generation datacom and telecom applications. An experimental study will be performed to verify the predictions of this approach. Basic modulator structures will be fabricated and characterized to quantify effective index changes induced in graphene through external voltages. The results of this study are expected to be a fundamental contribution to basic science that describes graphene.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With the advent of new applications such as social media, online medical records, cloud computing there is an astronomical increase in the data that is transmitted over the Internet and within the data centers. The only viable technology to transmit such vast amounts of information on demand is the fiber optics technology. This relies on transmitting optical radiation through optical fiber, which traps and guides optical radiation. However, information is almost always available in electrical form. Transmitting electrical information over the optical fiber requires optical modulators. Optical modulator imposes electrical information on the optical radiation which then transports electrical information over the optical fiber. Optical modulators are needed in large quantities and are desired to be very compact, low power consuming and low cost. Furthermore, their technology should allow integration with other devices to form high functionality microchips. This proposal investigated experimentally the possibility of such modulators using a novel material called graphene.

            Graphene is an arrangement of mono layer thick carbon atoms. It is theoretically predicted that electrical and optical properties of graphene can be modified by applying electric fields to graphene.  Experimental observation of this requires embedding graphene into an optical waveguide, which traps and guides the optical radiation just like an optical fiber. To subject graphene in the optical waveguide to electric fields, we use another graphene layer separated from the first with a thin insulating layer.  When a voltage is applied between these two graphene layers an electric field is generated, which changes the optical index and absorption of graphene layers. This in turn affects the transmission of light through the waveguide and optical modulation in response to applied electrical voltage is generated.

            In our work we started with graphene layers grown on copper foils. In this form graphene is not suitable for modulator applications and needs to be transferred onto suitable materials appropriate for optical waveguiding. We first developed techniques to transfer graphene layers on copper foils onto various different dielectrics with low defect density.  The quality of transferred graphene was verified by optical inspection, Raman spectra measurements and electrical measurements. In addition, low damage processing and patterning of graphene have been achieved, since graphene is extremely thin and is easily damaged during device fabrication. We found ways of encapsulating graphene to protect it from the chemical and mechanical damage introduced in standard device processing. This is followed by low resistance contact formation on graphene. Next dielectric waveguides containing double graphene layers were fabricated. Using electrical measurements, it was shown that electrical conductivity of one graphene layer was modulated or changed when a voltage is applied to the other layer. These waveguides also showed optical loss changes or modulation of the light through them when the voltage applied between the graphene layers was changed. Hence amplitude modulation was achieved. It was possible to get a factor of two change in the light amplitude in a waveguide containing only 100-micron long graphene. This is a very strong change and could be the basis of low cost and very compact optical modulators. Very good agreement was found with theoretical predictions. These calculations also predict very large index changes with very low loss modulation if higher electric fields between the graphene layers can be obtained. Measurements on interferometric devices also indicated strong index changes but presence of strong loss change made it difficult to determine the index change accurately. We needed to generated even higher electric fields to observe near pure index changes, but that was not possible in the fabricated devices due to dielectric breakdown. This can be achieved using a thinner dielectric and possibly a higher dielectric constant material in between the graphene layers. In addition, a higher index difference waveguide with higher optical confinement could improve the results several fold. These could be topics of future investigation. The experimental results obtained so far clearly shows that it is possible to make high quality optical waveguides containing double graphene layers that yield optical amplitude modulation when a voltage difference is applied between the graphene layers. The observed modulation agrees very well with calculations making graphene a promising material that can be engineered. This in turn has the potential to benefit the society and make a significant contribution to lower cost, higher performance data transmission using fiber optics.

            This project required a wide range of research activities ranging from device simulation, mask and process design, to advanced device fabrication and testing. As such it was an excellent educational vehicle in training a graduate student.  Furthermore, an undergraduate student was also involved in internship capacity and contributed to the design of optical waveguides. The results obtained were disseminated through several freshman seminars on photonics and photonic devices, as part of a chapter of a handbook and as presentations in international conferences.
